dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, I was reading something pretty wild about Kazakhstan today. Apparently, with a population of just over 20 million, it now means that every third Kazakhstani is, like, a car owner.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, I was reading something pretty wild about Kazakhstan today. Apparently, with a population of just over twenty million, it now means that every third Kazakhstani is, like, a car owner.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With a population of 20.33 million, this means that every third Kazakhstani is a car owner.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, every third person? That's, um, a lot higher than I would have guessed! How many cars are we talking about in total, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, every third person? That's, um, a lot higher than I would have guessed! How many cars are we talking about in total, then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it blew my mind too! As of June 1st, they've hit 6.3 million registered vehicles. And get this: in May alone, they registered nearly 128,100 new ones. That's almost 15% more than the same month last year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it blew my mind too! As of June first, they've hit six point three million registered vehicles. And get this: in May alone, they registered nearly one hundred twenty eight thousand, one hundred new ones. That's almost fifteen percent more than the same month last year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to data from the Bureau of National Statistics, as of June 1, 2025, the number of registered motor vehicles in Kazakhstan has reached 6.3 million. In May 2025 alone, 128,100 vehicles were registered " nearly 15% more than in the same month last year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's a massive surge for just one month. So, um, the national fleet grew by over half a million vehicles in just four months? That's, uh, pretty incredible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a massive surge for just one month. So, um, the national fleet grew by over half a million vehicles in just four months? That's, uh, pretty incredible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This means that over 526,000 vehicles were added to the national fleet in just four months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Most of those new registrations, by the way, were passenger cars â€“ like 113,000 units. But what's interesting is the eco-friendly side too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Most of those new registrations, by the way, were passenger cars - like one hundred thirteen thousand units. But what's interesting is the eco-friendly side too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most of the newly registered vehicles were passenger cars " totaling 113,000 units.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, like electric vehicles? I'm guessing those numbers are finally starting to climb?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, like electric vehicles? I'm guessing those numbers are finally starting to climb?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. The number of registered EVs went up by almost 67% compared to May 2024. Which is great, but, you know, traditional fuels are still, like, super dominant there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. The number of registered E V s went up by almost sixty seven percent compared to May twenty twenty four. Which is great, but, you know, traditional fuels are still, like, super dominant there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Interest in eco-friendly transport continues to grow: the number of registered electric vehicles increased by 66.9% compared to May 2024. However, traditional fuels are still dominant:

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's often the case, isn't it? You see the EV growth, but the overall picture is still, uh, very much reliant on petrol. And with all this growth, I imagine some cities are really feeling the squeeze.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's often the case, isn't it? You see the E V growth, but the overall picture is still, uh, very much reliant on petrol. And with all this growth, I imagine some cities are really feeling the squeeze.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Almaty, for instance. The article said they hit critical vehicle density as early as last year. Apparently, up to a million cars hit the city's roads *every single day*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Almaty, for instance. The article said they hit critical vehicle density as early as last year. Apparently, up to a million cars hit the city's roads every single day.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Almaty reached a critical vehicle density as early as last year. Each day, up to 1 million cars hit the city's roads, including 600,000 registered in Almaty and another 400,000 coming in from surrounding areas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A million cars? That's just... I can't even imagine that traffic. And, uh, a big chunk of those, like 400,000, are coming in from surrounding areas, not even registered in the city!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A million cars? That's just... I can't even imagine that traffic. And, uh, a big chunk of those, like four hundred thousand, are coming in from surrounding areas, not even registered in the city!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Each day, up to 1 million cars hit the city's roads, including 600,000 registered in Almaty and another 400,000 coming in from surrounding areas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. So, transport experts have been, like, suggesting things. You know, expanding paid parking zones, trying to limit unnecessary travel within the city.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. So, transport experts have been, like, suggesting things. You know, expanding paid parking zones, trying to limit unnecessary travel within the city.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Transport experts have previously suggested expanding paid parking zones and limiting unnecessary travel within the city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which makes sense, but then you see these numbers still just climbing, and you're like, are those measures even going to keep up?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes sense, but then you see these numbers still just climbing, and you're like, are those measures even going to keep up?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? It's a huge challenge. I guess everyone just wants their Camry or their Cobalt, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? It's a huge challenge. I guess everyone just wants their Camry or their Cobalt, huh?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Camry or Cobalt? Most common cars spotted on the streets of Astana and Almaty

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for sure. It's a tough balance between economic growth and, um, keeping cities actually livable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for sure. It's a tough balance between economic growth and, um, keeping cities actually livable.
